title: Between 8 March 2022 and 7 June 2022, will President Biden's approval rating fall below 38.5%?
preds: Note that he hasn't been able to get the job done...
Forgot to decay the probability with time, but anyways almost no chance now that we are so close to question close.
Agree with the crowd,  not likely to be that low by next week.
As we get close to the end, I think the probability rounds down to zero
Threshold is too low both circumstantially and historically
American Research Group has the lowest rating at 38 ½  All summed up is at 41%. It may stay like that to the end of this question
Maintaining that 1% in light of a new AP-NORC poll giving Biden an approval rating of 39%. Major time constraint and nature of weighting different polls may prevent the drop from going down as fast.
Declining 12 on passage of time and stability in the rating.
That would be a historic low over all time!
Very unlikely in current climate as sentiment turns against Putin
Recent supreme court ruling would make this less likely, IMO.
Factors that could cause his rating to plunge:  Gas prices above $7.15  Inflation 13%  Summer heat wave coinciding with fashion trend for heavy prairie dresses (c'mon Target!!)
Need to overcome significant inertia to move this figure.
Reducing further as Biden has been stable and the Supreme Court ruling will have influence.
like 42% now and some bad numbers for economy going to come out and more summer driving and gripping about high gas prices and midterm elections. and another fed hike

It doesn't seem as though most presidents fall below 38.5% in the first 2 years of presidency. Trump and Clinton are outliers, both had major scandals being constantly reported in the media.  One issue Biden faces is a poor economy. High gas prices and reverberating effects of Russian sanctions could have large negative economic impacts, which could then turn to affect Biden's approval negatively. Another potential problem is his handling of Ukraine - if he makes a move that proves a drastic mistake from the perspective of public opinion, that could damage his approval numbers. Basing my prediction on the probabilities of a major, news-reported scandal or major public opinion misstep in Ukraine.
Seems war is going US' way. Inflation coming down... but still likely a recession. However cut off is beginning of June
In challenging times such as this and with focus away from domestic matters, very unlikely
Time update  April 29 2022 41.7 - lowest 40.4 on February 27 2022 last report 41.8

Based on the current trends of his approval rating, I don't think he'll fall all the way down to 38.5% by 7 June 2022. It took 7 months for his rating to fall that same percentage amount, from 45% to 42%, and as of today, April 22, he still has a rating of 41.8%. I don't think such a drastic percentage drop would happen because several big events have already taken place during his administration, and his decline has remained steady. If he falls to 38.5%, I doubt it would happen before June 7.

~50 days for it to drop 3.1%, it was last 3.1% higher than it is now on Oct 27th. The slope doesn't seem steep enough to get there by June 7. Noise seems able to bounce the chart by 1-2%, but again, it doesn't seem like quite enough. The chances of a day falling below 38.5% would require either a) some bad new cycle (1-2%) or b) the trend to accelerate and there to be a particularly noisy day (<1%). Going 2% overall

I think currently the odds are low because of the polarity of the US. While I'm sure most Republicans will disprove of Biden no matter what he does, a similar number of the Democrats will be favorable towards Biden no matter what. When it comes to the moderate and independents, it's less clear but as the country has become more polarized, there are fewer of them in the first place. For those who moderate or independent, the question becomes how to model well informed they are and what their key perception indicators are.
Dropping this further as even more unlikely with current events.
I can't picture current numbers changing that drastically.

His approval rating is substantially tied to perceptions of Covid and to world events. Had Russia not invaded the Ukraine, I suspect his ratings would have risen somewhat in the early years of 2022, but because of the invasion, they stayed lower than they otherwise would have given the gradual lessening of Covid impact. I suspect the Russia/Ukraine crisis will resolve prior to June 2022 and public perception of President Biden will not continue to decline.
With conflict still going expect this to stay same.
Target level is the lower bound of the current prediction.  It would take one blunder to drop below.  Staying put for now.
I believe this will close soon yes

Repeating forecast. It would take a major, unprecedented dip for Biden's approval rating to fall below 38.5%. It has been stably in the range from 40.4% to 44% since last October, and it hasn't been below 40.4% since he took office last year. It would also be extremely unusual for a Democratic president's approval rating to fall that low. I think the real chance that his approval rating would fall below 38.5% is <1%, but I'll leave some margin for error.
Very unlikely as support will be with president in face of global issues just now.
Nah, i think his floor is about 40%. He'd have to do something crazy between now and then.
-10 to hedge toward the crowd a bit, but I expect while he will probably stay in the 40 to 45 range world events are volatile enough that I can't write off the possibility of him reaching 38.5%.
With the ongoing crisis, Biden will gain support and more likely that his level of support will go up.
I think the real risk is <1%, but the penalty is so steep for being wrong. Not worth taking that risk.
Increasing from 2% to 4% because Jackson is almost a shoe-in and some people will misattribute their dislike of (read: latent racism or implicit bias against) Jackson to Biden.

A bit of a downward creep and 7 June is a long time for that slope to play out.  If Ketanji-Brown and Ukraine don't give him a boost,  then inflation might have a play.  Will hold for now even though the crowd is less convinced.

Not changing probability for now, but interesting lens to consider is that the June 7 deadline seems to be chosen since its when a bunch of primary elections are (https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2022/politics/2022-midterm-election-calendar/), so there's probably going to be a lot of advertising in the run-up to it presumably bashing Biden.
current approval hasn't dipped below 40.4% (on Feb 28)  and currently sitting at 42.1% - the next couple of weeks are going to be interesting on how things go
Inflation and gas prices outpacing supreme court momentum.

Current Approval: 45.0%
Distance to threshold: 3.5%
Days remaining: 74
Lowest Point So Far: 40.4% on Feb 27

I agree with @Emking - even after the Russian invasion, approval rating did not go below 40%. Besides, it will probably go up a bit since it is very likely that Ketanji Brown Jackson will be confirmed to the Supreme Court within the specified dates.
No not with the Ukraine war and split along party lines …
People need leadership in a time of crisis, so this could help Biden.
There appears to be a floor of support at about 40%.
Barring something unseen Biden’s staunchest supporters will not care what he does.
Visually extrapolating, it seems improbable, and during war (in Ukraine), people tend to stand more behind their leaders.

Usually less bashing, at least at the beginning of a war but it is an election year. We're being distracted from many of the chronic problems. But Afganistan and Federal spending, deficit are upsetting. Only 50% sure it won't fall below 38.5.

period: 3 months	
approach: frequency approval below 38.5 of Joe Biden	
excel shows 0.6%	
90% projection interval only includes a very small surface that's below 38.5% (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/)
from what I can see with the naked eye 1/25 of the surface is below 38.5% > 4%	
4%*90% accuracy+10%*50% (if predictions fall outside range and are under average) = 8.6% 	
Joe Biden's handling of the conflict in ukraine has an expected positive effect on his approval rate. dont know to what extent the projection took that into account.	
I'll take the middle of both values. > 5%

A lot fewer folks seem to be blaming him for high petrol and other prices.   This is a pleasant surprise for Biden, and also for anyone who is heartened by evidence that amurricans can occasionally formulate rational notions of cause and effect.  Mightn't last, though; that would be asking a lot.

Taking the outside view, the base rate for that is fairly low. Several presidents have reached below that level, but typically only for fairly brief periods of time. I would estimate the base rate for it at 10%. However, taking the inside view I will increase the chances for Biden, because the base rate also shows that there have been fairly steep declines over a short period are not unheard of, such as George H.W. Bush and Jimmy Carter, and Biden is only a little above 40%, and he's facing a pretty volatile set of challenges where it would be easy to imagine his rating plummeting, if for example NATO was drawn into war with Russia or perhaps if Russia annexes Ukraine. Not to mention the chances that inflation continues to increase and pushes approval ratings down further.

Reaffirming my prior forecast:  A few things set me up for a strong prior that this will not happen:
- Trump only just barely bottomed out around there
- Biden's floor of support, even after the much maligned withdrawal from Afghanistan was still in the low 40s
- There may be a slight rally-around-the-flag effect in force with the Russian invasion of Ukraine None of these really point me towards Biden reaching particularly high approval ratings, but I don't see how he gets to 38.5% all of a sudden.

Quite consistent rating so far and not dissimilar from previous presidents, tends to be quite heavily impacted by inflation rates which whilst rising could cause it to lower, but set as small chance at present.

Rethinking my stance after reading this, going slightly higher than my previous estimate
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/is-bidens-approval-rating-really-rebounding/

The president continues to be perceived as weak regarding his response to the Ukraine incident and conversations with China.  As the mid-term elections approach, the rhetoric from the Republicans will also likely drive down the approval rating.  However, I will update my assessment if the president's actions result in improved perceived support for Ukraine or if he takes steps domestically to reduce inflation or improve the economy in other ways which will likely result in higher bi-partisan approval ratings.

Slow decline at this point in his presidency would be on par with previous presidents, but barring something drastic it doesn't seem like it would drop so quickly in a few months. A major misstep is always possible.
A chanc given inflation, oil price and interest rates. But he seems to be holding steady so I doubt it would sink before June

@ktk374 made a fair "outside view" comment on the history of Presidential ratings heading into a midterm. Just my own scan of historic approval ratings confirms the suspicion that breaking below 38.5% is highly unusual. So I'll start with a base scenario of 5%. That said it does look like Jimmy Carter's approval rating sank below that threshold during the stagflation crisis (rising rates / energy crisis / geopolitical risk). So I am elevating the likelihood given the comparability to today. Not for nothing either but there's a lot of market commentary about today's market environment and 1994 (rising inflation and a Fed raising interest rates into a  mid-term year)...Clinton did see his approval drop a touch below 40%, but not through 38.5% (though he started the year at a better approval rating than Biden). All things considered I do think it's not likely given historic evidence.
Not this unlikely to happen during his presidency, but really quite unlikely to happen in this window.
This would be the lower 90th percentile band of where he currently sits which has been stable since the dive he took in 2021.

With the exception of Donald Trump, no president’s approval rating has dipped as low as 38.5% before the midterm elections (1/46 presidents; 2%). However, there is nothing currently that makes me think Biden’s current approval rating of around 42.9% will dip 4.5 points (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/biden-approval-rating/?cid=rrpromo).

The mid-terms are in sight, and right now (3/17), Biden lacks major policy project or wins, which explains his slump in the polls. However, significant attacks from across the aisle seem weak so far. Until June, they will increase. Still, there will be a move by democrats since they desperately need a win. Manchin and other troublemakers in Biden's camp seem willing for new projects and renegotiation on others. This could come just in time, especially as long as democrats still hold this much power.

3/17: Approval numbers are fairly stable and divided across party lines.  Add onto that the fact that there is a crisis right now and I doubt there would be anything other than upside for the president.  Numbers are holding steady and discontent with inflation has been offset by wide public support for Ukraine (versus Russia).

Moving my base rate as I check the crowd rationales for this to be in the cards...what makes this time different? is the question I re-ask in doing this move towards "no."  However, I only move slightly below 50% given the amount of uncertainty and unprecedented world events with loads of uncertainty baked into each of them.  I expect a significant shift come mid-Apr or earlier, one way or the other.
I see much more potential upside for Biden than opportunity for additional downside

Biden popularity has been pretty stable between 40pc and 45pc.  Given that views in the US are so party oriented, views on the president are pretty fixed and it will take a big shock to move the numbers substantially.  There will definitely a bit of a boost in support at the moment due to what is happening in Europe, and also over time popularity tends to wane.  And there is plenty of opportunity for a major blunder or mistake.  But I feel it would have to be a big event for popularity to drop this far.

Looking back at the polls for former presidents on the 538 site, three presidents (Trump, Clinton, and Ford) seemed to drop below 39% approval in their first two years, with a few others closer or doing so later (HW Bush, Reagan, Carter).  Only three of the last nine never dipped that low (Obama, W Bush, and Nixon). From the current 42$ level, Biden does not have much room.  Inflation seems to be a current challenge for him, with some positives coming from the current COVID situation and his response to Putin's invasion of Ukraine.  All of those could change.  The coming mid-term election is likely to lead candidates to criticize the current situation, leading to criticism of Biden himself.   Helpful perspectives also from @cpschneider [1] and @Deerslayer [2]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1417025
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1416977

Decline of approval seemed quite steady since he took office. The delince from 47.1% to the current 42.5% took more than seven months. If the average delince rate is continuing as it has since July 2021, it seems unlikely that his approval rate will lose another 4.3% in 3 months. However, non-linear developments of the approval rate are possible. Historic data suggest (visual inspection of the lower part of the website), that such changes can go in both direction, but seem equally likely to be positive as negative. Nevertheless 38.5 % would be a low in recenty history after roughly 500 days. The outside view therefore suggests a low probability. Given the current circumstance, a increased decline rate can not fully excluded, even though approval rates of other Presidents generally seem to have profited from wars in other countries.
Biden's approval has fallen at least in part due to inflation has risen. But still his state of union address has gained some points in his favor and handling of Ukraine and Russia issue.

Presidential approval rating historical trends were observed with all existing data in the following way to form an outside base rate:
-Averages of previous presidents (by party as well)
-Rate within a period of previous presidents in the given timeframe
-Year of the term (2nd)
-Time of year (Spring-Summer)
-Existence or emergence of crisis (diplomatic, military, pandemic) This shows a Day 416 average of 53.68 and a 51.38 at Day 504, for an overall average decrease of 2.3 points putting an initial (and outside view only) of 40.4 for 7 June 2022.  An attempt to overlay current global events in a general manner was made, with economics as the focus.  Those presidents dealing with economic and military crises combined saw a larger rate of decreasing popularity. Couple this with the inside view of Biden's current rate (just over 42%), expected poor economic performance, pandemic struggles, the war in Ukraine, and high prices/inflation persisting it is much likely to continue decreasing.
One would expect a rally round the flag due to the Ukraine crisis in particular.
VERY unlikely. Were it not for the uncertainty caused by the war in Ukraine, I'd have this prediction much lower.

I am at a bit of a loss to come up with a useful distribution to generate probabilities but finger in the air it seems possible but not very likely.   This data looks mean reverting and also has some seasonal trends like the drop that happens for Biden, Obama, and Trump during the first 420 days.  Besides that there also appear to be near term trends in the data with the changes up and down clustering for a couple of months a time.   Qualitatively polarisation should anchor the approval rating around 50% which is roughly the population share of each party when they vote for presidents.  And the overseas war dominating news coverage seems like it would have a rally around the flag effect meaning near term changes would favour higher approvals.  Maybe sanctions weighing on the economy and promoting inflation pressure would push approval lower but that seems like it would take longer than the question horizon.

That would be an extraordinary fall. It's not impossible, so I'll go with 2%, but I can't picture it happening on the short timescale of the question. I think it would take something extraordinary to push Biden's ratings that low. Inflation hasn't done it so far, either.
Approval rating 42.9% as of today, and a bit on the rise presumably because of Ukraine.  But high gas prices, partisanship, general inflation could drag this down.
Pretty darn unlikely, given Biden’s very stable approval ratings over the past several months, and given the extreme political polarization of the public.

A few things set me up for a strong prior that this will not happen:
- Trump only just barely bottomed out around there
- Biden's floor of support, even after the much maligned withdrawal from Afghanistan was still in the low 40s
- There may be a slight rally-around-the-flag effect in force with the Russian invasion of Ukraine None of these really point me towards Biden reaching particularly high approval ratings, but I don't see how he gets to 38.5% all of a sudden.

I think with the hyper partisan nature of politics in the US, the floor for approval ratings have been risen. 40% for both Biden and Trump appeared to be a significant level of support, with Trump dipping a bit below 40% occasionally but never by too far and always reverting back above 40% pretty quickly. Similarly Biden has be falling gradually throughout his term but seems to have found a floor around 42%, with him briefly dipping almost to 40% before quickly rebounding. Ultimately I think for Biden to drop to 38.5% something really need to go wrong for him. What I am seeing shows absolutely no indication that will happen. If anything I think a competent response against Russia, COVID progressing to the endemic stage, central banks beginning rate hikes to tackle inflation, and historically low ratings at the moment lead me to believe the path of least resistance is higher. I am leaving a 1% chance of a critical mistake tanking his approval, but I ultimately think that is just too low of an approval rating for him to hit before June 7th

Monte Carlo using his entire presidency puts it at 0%. Thus far he's somewhat mirrored Obama's first term but lower by 6-7%, and at 500 days the lowest that would put him is still >40%.  There is no shortage of uncertainty right now though, primarily around inflation and gas prices that could push him lower. There's also obviously Ukraine, though that's been handled fairly well so far. Uncertainty there pushes both ways, being a wartime president is generally good, while responding weakly or mishandling the conflict could push him lower. We've seen movement of ~12% over the course of his presidency, so an additional 5% lower is quite a significant move. <38.5% was low even for Trump. Certainly not likely, but its hard to rule it out entirely during turbulent times.
Base rate is ~2.5% judging by how many quarters of the last 3 presidents there were that dropped below 38.5%

Seems very unlikely- Historically a very rare occurrence for approval to fall this low and during a time of conflict with Russia and brooding tensions with China there is likely to be a sustained mini bump in approval
